title: The family living on Kenyan safari camp where elephants roam free
text:
960 shares 20
View
comments
Saba Douglas-Hamilton and Frank Pope really do live a wild life.
At the home they share with their three daughters in the middle of Kenya's Samburu National Reserve there are no barriers or fences - so elephants, lions, snakes and monkeys roam free.
A new BBC series, beginning on Monday August 31, will give an insight into their unpredictable and occasionally chaotic lives as they run a safari camp and an elephant conservation charity while bring up their small children.
Life in Africa's outback: Saba Douglas-Hamilton (far right) pictured with her husband, father and daughters
Driven family: Saba and the girls gaze across the landscape from a Land Rover
A Kenya Wildlife Service vet loads a tranquiliser dart into a gun fitted with a telescopic sight
Frank Pope pictured in the bush searching for the biggest bull elephant in North Kenya
This is the first year that Saba has tried to run the family business and she and Frank face some dramatic challenges living on this frontier, from monkeys in the kitchen, to rescuing a baby elephant and even a giant crocodile.
As well as the wildlife, the series will see the family deal with floods threatening to wash away the camp, medical emergencies, animals in trouble, financial crises and food deliveries that just don't turn up.

Animal expert Saba , 45, and her team certainly have their work cut out to make the lodge and family life in one of Africa's most stunning locations endeavours that work.
The community of around 500 elephants that live in the area often treat the camp like a dating hot spot, which adds to the drama.
'During rainy season they come here looking for a mate. It's like their Christmas time, they get very fat and start feeling sexy,' Saba tells MailOnline Travel.
Gentle giants: A community of around 500 elephants lives happily at the camp all year around
Saba's daughters Selkie, 6 and Luna and Mayian, both 4, are entertained by Sammy, a Samburu warrior
She arrived in Kenya with her father in 1997, aged 18, and help the conservation charity and a research camp to observe and research the animal's behaviour.
Now an established conservation operation, tourists are invited to stay on their camp and witness the behaviour of the elephants and the relationships between animals and humans up close.
The goings on among the elephant families are much like a soap opera, she says, and each one is known by name. 'The researchers will say "you'll never believe who's been mating with Ronald!".
Litus and Mporian: Samburu warriors living in the Kenya's Samburu National Reserve
Out in the sticks: Saba and her eldest daughter Selkie, who loves living in the wild surrounded by nature
Saba and Frank produce beaming smiles for a protrait shot, as a bull elephant photobombs them
Frank checks on a bull elephant called Edison during radio collaring
With no fences, there are no boundaries between man and nature. But is it dangerous having such huge, wild animals running free?
'Elephants are so like us. In fact, humans are much more unpredictable. They share with us feelings of love, envy, grief, joy, compassion - and even a sense of their own mortality.
'I've seen unrelated elephants trying to raise a dying elephant to its feet before. They have a similar intelligence to humans.'
Saba's daughters with a baby elephant. The children are very happy to be in nature and are schooled at home
'Elephants share with us feelings of love, envy, grief, joy, compassion and even a sense of their own mortality'
A cheetah at the Samburu National Reserve. All kinds of animals are free to wander in this huge wilderness
The experienced wildlife presenter describes a night when she slept under the stars in a dry river bed in Namibia.
'I woke up very suddenly and suddenly saw a huge elephant bull, just yards away from me.
'He stopped and looked at me and started walking slowly towards me'.
'"What can I do?" I thought. "I can't run, he'll kill me."
'So I decided to play dead. He got so close that he blocked the moonlight. Then he reached out his trunk - and just smelled me.
'He was less than a metre and a half away from me. I lay there with my heart beating in my chest, and then he just walked away.'
'Afterwards, there was just an explosion of joy, at being alive. And also, at the grace of an elephant.'
Samburu wildlife guides and trackers, Bernard and Litus, take Elephant Watch guests on safari
Nile crocodiles waiting for dinner. Snakes and scorpions are also common sightings at the safari camp
Happy days: Saba, who's lived in Kenya for 18 years, poses with a smiling Elephant Watch camp team
Being in the heart of Kenya's Samburu National Reserve, it's not just elephants roaming free. Leopard, hyena, monkeys, snakes and lions also wander through the camp.
But when it comes to the three daughters, Selkie, six and twins Luna and Mayian, four, scorpions are the biggest threat. They can be fatal, says Saba.
Despite living in Kenya for 18 years, she has only seen one black mamba - Africa's most dangerous snake. 'They're more afraid of you than you are of them believe it or not,' she says.
But there was one occasion which made her fear for her children's safety.
Maternal moment: A lioness and her cub admire their surroundings at the Samburu National Reserve
Dressed to impress: Samburu warriors wear their brightest ensembles in preparation for a celebration
It's feeding time at the elephant orphanage. The elephants provide a lot of drama for Saba and her family and are much loved
An elephant family, including two very young animals, wander through Samburu during a drought
Brutal reality: Two lion sisters and their cubs feed on a zebra that they've killed
'It was when I heard that there was a leopard that got rabies rampaging around through towns, that I realised we'd need something of a ninja nanny.
'I needed to find a way of dealing with the very real possibility of something happening to them. What would I do if we were faced with a rabid jackal?
'So I employed a Samburu warrior from the local tribe to keep the kids safe from the snakes and the lions.
'He's a herder, so I pay him to herd the children as well - we joke that it's like herding cats.'
'The children adore him, he's their best friend, and he takes them on adventures. He teaches them how to milk cows and shows them where the crocodiles hide.
Saba's husband Frank Pope, pictured with his Save the Elephants plane
A young elephant called Sokotei gets to know his new keeper (left) and a lioness and her cub prowl the savannah
'He's teaching them songs, dances and survival techniques.'
The girls, who are home-schooled, don't have traditional toys, instead they make entertainment from the nature around them, learning much more about biology and different cultures than they would in a classroom.
This Wild Life begins on BBC 2 on Mondays and Tuesdays at 7pm, from August 31.
For more information about staying at the camp visit www.elephantwatchportfolio.com and see www.savetheelephants.org for more details on the conservation charity.
